docs.title: Who This Wiki is For
docs.text:
This wiki is written for ERRSA MC committee members, admins, and developers responsible for operating the server.

If you are moderating in-game only, most sections here are reference material and not required reading.

docs.title: Wiki Rules
docs.text:
Documentation discipline

If you update or add a plugin, update the wiki the same day.

Source of truth

This wiki is the handoff reference for future ERRSA MC admins.

This knowledgebase is the authoritative operational reference for the ERRSA Minecraft server.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
How the ERRSA MC server is structured, where systems live, and how changes are made safely.

You are not expected to memorize this page

docs.title: You are expected to know where answers live and when to escalate
Purpose
docs.text: This page orients new ERRSA MC committee members, admins, and developers to how the server is built and operated. It provides a high-level overview of systems, access, and workflows before any technical changes are made.

docs.title: Who this is for
docs.text:
• Incoming ERRSA MC committee members
  • Admins and Developers assuming operational responsibility

docs.title: Who can skip most of this
docs.text:
• Moderators acting only in-game
  • Staff not responsible for server configuration

docs.title: System overview (high level)
docs.text:
• Game server: Minecraft (Paper)
  • Hosting provider: Apex Hosting
  • Management panel: Apex Panel
  • Database: MySQL (via phpMyAdmin)
  • Permissions: LuckPerms
  • Source of truth: This wiki

docs.title: Hosting Operations
docs.text:
• Access: Admins, Developers, MC Lead, and ERRSA Exec

  • Primary responsibilities:

  • Server uptime
  • File access
  • Backups
  • Database hosting

docs.title: Server files
docs.text:
Accessible through the Apex Panel → File Manager or FTP File Access.

Common locations:

  • /plugins/ — all plugin .jar files
  • /plugins/<PluginName>/ — plugin configs and data
  • /logs/ — crash reports and runtime logs
  • /world*/ — world data (do not edit casually)

docs.title: Database
docs.text:
• Tool: phpMyAdmin (via Apex)
  • Used for:
  • Player initialization
  • Email verification
  • External registration systems

Warning

Never manually edit database tables unless the plugin documentation explicitly says it is safe.

docs.title: Backups
docs.text:
• Provided by: Apex Hosting
  • Cadence: (document exact schedule here)
  • Scope:
  • World files
  • Plugin configs
  • Player data

Danger

Never update plugins or configs without a recent backup.

docs.title: Golden rules
docs.text:
1. No backup = no change
  2. Document every plugin or config change in this wiki AND in the changelog (LINK HERE)
  3. Never give players permissions directly — use Luckyperm groups

Breaking these rules is how servers get corrupted.

docs.title: Safe workflow
docs.text:
1. Confirm a recent backup exists
  2. Make the change
  3. Restart the server
  4. Verify functionality
  5. Update documentation

docs.title: Unsafe workflow (do not do this)
docs.text:
• Editing live configs without backup
  • Reloading plugins blindly (never reload)
  • Making undocumented changes

docs.title: ERRSA MC — Operational Review & Navigation
docs.text:
This page provides a single entry point to all operational documentation for the ERRSA Minecraft server.

If you are reviewing, onboarding, or taking over responsibility, start here.

docs.title: Core training modules
docs.text:
These modules explain how the server works and how authority is structured.

  1. Module 1 — Server Architecture & Authority Model How permissions, identity, and authority are intentionally separated.

  2. Module 2 — Core Systems & Player Flow How players move from first join to survival gameplay.

  3. Module 3 — Core Operational Plugins Which plugins are core, what they own, and how to diagnose issues.

  4. Module 4 — Documentation, Change Control & Incident Context Which document governs which action and how to operate safely.

  5. Module 5 — Advanced Systems & Developer Responsibility High-risk systems, long-term responsibility, and trust boundaries.

docs.title: Authoritative documents (official)
docs.text:
These documents define authority, procedure, and records. If there is ever a conflict, these take precedence over the wiki.

  • 📘 ERRSA Minecraft Staff Documentation Authority, roles, procedures, escalation, and moderation rules.

  • 🧾 ERRSA MC Moderation Log Record of all player-facing enforcement actions.

  • 🛠️ ERRSA MC Server Changelog Record of all system and configuration changes.

docs.title: Reference sections
docs.text:
These pages are used as needed, not read linearly.

  • Getting Started Orientation, system overview, and safety rules.

  • Permissions Model Detailed explanation of MAIN / ERRSA / STAFF tracks.

  • Plugins Per-plugin reference documentation.

  • Troubleshooting Common failures and where to look first.

docs.title: Review checklist (for handoff or audit)
docs.text:
You are ready to operate or take over the server if you can:

  • Identify which document governs a given situation
  • Trace a player from first join → survival
  • Name the core operational plugins and their responsibilities
  • Follow change control without improvising
  • Escalate instead of guessing

docs.title: Final note
docs.text:
This wiki explains how the server works. The official documents define what you are allowed to do.

Use both correctly.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This module explains how the ERRSA Minecraft server is intentionally structured. Before learning commands, plugins, or configs, you must understand how authority, identity, and gameplay access are separated.

This module answers one question: “Who is allowed to do what — and why?”

You do not need to memorize this module.

You need to understand the boundaries it defines.

docs.title: Core principle
docs.text:
The ERRSA MC server uses parallel authority tracks, not a single permission ladder.

Belonging to one track never grants power in another.

docs.title: Visual Overview
docs.text:
Interactive Permissions Model

Hover over each role to see what it means and what it does not imply.

MAIN Player Lifecycle
  • default unverified
  • user verified
  • premium VIP cosmetic
ERRSA Identity errsa hallrep legacy execcoord execboard advisor

Identity roles describe your relationship to ERRSA (not staff authority).

STAFF Authority
  • mod
  • admin
  • dev

docs.title: MAIN track — Player lifecycle
docs.text: The MAIN track controls whether a player can interact with the server at all. It does not control authority or organizational status.

docs.title: ERRSA track — Organization & identity
docs.text:
The ERRSA track represents a player’s identity within the organization, not their power on the server.

Examples:

  • Executive board members
  • Hall representatives
  • Legacy members
  • Advisor

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Prefixes and recognition
  • Organizational identity
  • Historical or honorary roles

ERRSA roles never grant moderation, admin, or developer permissions.

docs.title: STAFF track — Authority
docs.text: The STAFF track controls actions that affect other players or the server itself.

docs.title: Levels (conceptual only)
docs.text:
• Moderator
    • Rule enforcement
    • Investigations
    • Muting / kicking / banning
  • Admin
    • Incident resolution
    • Rollbacks and overrides
    • Server stability actions
  • Developer
    • Plugins and configs
    • Permissions architecture
    • Backend systems

docs.title: Escalation logic (conceptual)
docs.text:
• Player behavior issues → Moderator
  • Server damage or incidents → Admin
  • Plugin, config, or permissions issues → Developer

If you are unsure which track an issue belongs to, escalate upward rather than acting.

docs.title: Next module
docs.text:
• Module 2 — Core Systems & Player Flow Learn how players move through verification, initialization, and core infrastructure. Start Module 2

Last reviewed: 2025-02-13 | Applies to current ERRSA MC server network

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This module explains how a player moves through the ERRSA Minecraft server from their first join to active survival gameplay.

It focuses on understanding the system, not fixing it.

By the end of this module, you should be able to answer: “Where in the system is this player right now, and what owns that state?”

ℹ️ You are not expected to change configurations or permissions after this module. You are expected to recognize what is normal, what is incomplete, and when to escalate.

docs.title: The Player Lifecycle (High Level)
docs.text:
Every new player follows the same automated path:

  1. Join the server
  2. Enter the PlayerInit world (void world)
  3. Agree to server rules
  4. Register with a university email
  5. Receive approval or denial via email
  6. On approval:
  7. Permissions are updated automatically
  8. Player is teleported to Survival spawn

No staff action is required for normal verification.

docs.title: PlayerInit World
docs.text: PlayerInit is a Multiverse void world that exists solely for new player onboarding.

docs.title: What PlayerInit is
docs.text:
• The entry point for all new players
  • A controlled environment for verification
  • An expected and intentional state

docs.title: What players can do
docs.text:
• Agree or disagree to rules
  • Run /register
  • Complete email verification
  • Wait for approval

docs.title: What players cannot do
docs.text:
• Access survival gameplay
  • Chat in the main world
  • Bypass verification

If a player is in PlayerInit, the system is working as intended. They have not completed verification yet.

docs.title: Email Verification & SQL (Conceptual)
docs.text:
When a player runs /register:

  • Their Minecraft username, UUID, and email are recorded
  • Their verification status is stored in a database column

docs.title: Approval / denial behavior
docs.text:
Approve: - Status column updates - PlayerInit detects the change - LuckPerms promotion is executed - Player is teleported automatically Deny: - Status column updates - Player is kicked - Player may retry on reentry

Verification is fully automated. Staff do not manually approve players.

docs.title: LuckPerms in the Verification Flow
docs.text: LuckPerms is used to enforce access, not decide eligibility.

docs.title: What LuckPerms does
docs.text:
• Promotes players from default → user
  • Enables survival gameplay access
  • Applies the correct MAIN track permissions

docs.title: What LuckPerms does not do
docs.text:
• Store emails
  • Decide who is verified
  • Grant staff authority

LuckPerms applies decisions made by other systems. It does not make those decisions itself.

docs.title: Java vs Bedrock Players
docs.text: The server supports both Java and Bedrock players.

docs.title: Bedrock-specific behavior
docs.text:
• Bedrock players join via Geyser/Floodgate
  • Their usernames appear with a . prefix
  • They must specify a port when joining

docs.title: Important notes
docs.text:
• The . prefix is expected
  • Verification works the same way for Bedrock players
  • Username formatting alone is not an error

docs.title: Velocity & Server Layout (Overview)
docs.text: The network uses a Velocity proxy.

docs.title: Current servers
docs.text:
• Survival (Main) — default destination
  • Event — separate server
  • Backup — separate server

Players always enter through Velocity. Server separation is intentional and controlled.

This section will expand as infrastructure grows.

docs.title: Worlds Inside Survival
docs.text:
The Survival server contains multiple worlds:

  • Survival world — main gameplay
  • PlayerInit — verification only
  • Legacy Lake — Hall of Fame for former ERRSA leadership

Legacy Lake is preserved intentionally and should not be modified casually.

docs.title: Common Player Issues (Identification Only)
docs.text:
This module does not authorize fixes. It teaches recognition.

“I’m stuck in the void”

  • Player is in PlayerInit
  • Verification incomplete

“I verified but nothing happened”

  • PlayerInit loop has not processed approval yet
  • SQL → LuckPerms promotion pending

“My name looks weird”

  • Bedrock player via Floodgate
  • Expected behavior

“I can’t join on Bedrock”

  • Likely join address or port issue
  • Geyser/Floodgate related

docs.title: What This Module Does NOT Authorize
docs.text:
After completing this module, you are not authorized to:

  • Edit database entries
  • Change LuckPerms groups
  • Teleport players out of PlayerInit
  • Manually bypass verification

If action is required, escalate.

docs.title: Module 2 Completion Check
docs.text:
You have completed this module if you can:

  • Describe the full player lifecycle
  • Explain why PlayerInit exists
  • Identify which system owns a player’s state
  • Help a player understand what step they are on

docs.title: Next module
docs.text:
• Module 3 — Core Operational Plugins Learn about our core plugins that keeps the server operational Start Module 3

Last reviewed: 2025-02-13 | Applies to current ERRSA MC production server

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This module introduces the core operational plugins that staff interact with during day-to-day server operations.

These plugins are considered core because:

  • They affect player access or safety
  • They are involved in most incidents or questions
  • Misuse can cause widespread impact

This module focuses on what each plugin owns, not how to reconfigure it.

docs.title: What counts as a core operational plugin
docs.text:
A plugin is considered core operational if:

  • It affects who can play
  • It affects how players move between systems
  • It affects moderation or safety
  • Staff interact with it during incidents

Plugins that add cosmetics, QoL, or gameplay features are reference-only and documented elsewhere.

docs.title: What it owns
docs.text:
• New player onboarding
  • PlayerInit world behavior
  • Verification polling loop
  • Automated teleport after approval
  • Triggering LuckPerms promotion

docs.title: What it does NOT own
docs.text:
• Email approval decisions
  • Permission structure
  • Staff authority

docs.title: What it owns
docs.text:
• Group membership
  • Permission enforcement
  • MAIN / ERRSA / STAFF track separation

docs.title: What it does NOT own
docs.text:
• Player verification
  • Organizational identity decisions
  • Manual promotion for access

docs.title: What they own
docs.text:
• Bedrock → Java protocol translation
  • Username formatting (. prefix)
  • Cross-platform compatibility

docs.title: What they do NOT own
docs.text:
• Permissions logic
  • Verification decisions
  • Server routing

docs.title: What it owns
docs.text:
• Entry point for all connections
  • Routing players to servers
  • Server separation and isolation

docs.title: What it does NOT own
docs.text:
• World management
  • Permissions
  • Plugin behavior inside servers

docs.title: Core vs reference plugins
docs.text: Plugins are classified based on impact, not importance.

docs.title: Core plugins
docs.text:
Core plugins are systems that:

  • Control player access, identity, or authority
  • Affect multiple players or the entire server
  • Are involved in onboarding, moderation, or recovery
  • Can cause widespread disruption if misconfigured

Because of this:

  • Core plugins are covered in training modules
  • Core plugin changes must be documented in the server changelog
  • Issues involving core plugins are escalated

docs.title: Reference plugins
docs.text:
Reference plugins are systems that:

  • Affect gameplay features or quality-of-life
  • Impact individual players or small groups
  • Do not control access, authority, or onboarding
  • Can usually be disabled or adjusted without system-wide impact

Because of this:

  • Reference plugins are documented for lookup
  • Reference plugin changes must be documented in the server changelog
  • Reading them is not required for training
  • Changes are lower-risk and more localized

docs.title: Incident Ownership Mapping (Gold Section)
docs.text:
This is where admins gain operational intuition.

If the problem is…

Player cannot play → PlayerInitialization / LuckPerms

Permissions feel wrong → LuckPerms (but check upstream first)

Bedrock player can’t join → Floodgate / Geyser / join info

Player in wrong server → Velocity

docs.title: This module does not authorize
docs.text:
• Editing configs
  • Reloading plugins
  • Using LuckPerms editor
  • Modifying Velocity routing
  • Manual player promotion

docs.title: Module 3 completion check
docs.text:
You have completed this module if you can:

  • Identify the correct system before taking action
  • Explain why a plugin is or is not responsible for an issue
  • Escalate appropriately without making unauthorized changes

docs.title: Module 4 — Documentation, Change Control, & Incident Context
Purpose
docs.text:
This module explains which official documents govern which actions on the ERRSA Minecraft server, and how to use them correctly.

This module is a guide, not a source of authority.

  • All procedures, punishments, and staff actions are defined in official documentation.
  • All player-facing enforcement is recorded in official logs.
  • All server changes are recorded in official changelogs.

This module teaches how those documents work together.

Warning

If there is ever a conflict between this module and an official document, the official document always takes precedence.

docs.title: The authoritative documents
docs.text: The ERRSA MC server is governed by three official documents. Each has a distinct purpose and authority.

docs.title: ERRSA Minecraft Staff Documentation
docs.text:
(Authority & Procedure)

What it governs:

  • Staff roles and chain of command
  • Conduct expectations
  • Moderation procedures
  • Punishments, appeals, and escalation
  • Logging requirements

What it answers:

  • “What am I allowed to do?”
  • “What is the correct procedure?”
  • “How should this situation be handled?”

Official authority:

ERRSA Minecraft Staff Documentation

docs.title: ERRSA MC Moderation Log
docs.text:
(Record of Player-Facing Actions)

What it records:

  • Warnings
  • Mutes, kicks, bans
  • Administrative actions affecting players
  • Evidence and notes tied to enforcement

What it answers:

  • “What action was taken against a player?”
  • “When and why did it happen?”
  • “Who took the action?”

Official record:

ERRSA MC Moderation Log

docs.title: ERRSA MC Server Changelog
docs.text:
(Record of System Changes)

What it records:

  • Plugin additions and updates
  • Configuration changes
  • Infrastructure changes
  • Version history

What it answers:

  • “What changed on the server?”
  • “When did it change?”
  • “Why was it changed?”

Official record:

ERRSA MC Server Changelog

docs.title: Where this module fits
docs.text:
This module does not:

  • Define punishments
  • Authorize staff actions
  • Replace official procedures
  • Serve as a log

This module does:

  • Explain which document to use
  • Reinforce documentation discipline
  • Provide context for safe operation
  • Teach judgment and escalation

Info

Think of this module as a map, not a rulebook.

docs.title: Which document do I use?
docs.text:
Situation Use this document Player broke a rule Staff Documentation Issuing a warning / ban Moderation Log Player appeals a ban Staff Documentation Plugin updated Server Changelog Config changed Server Changelog Server behaves differently Server Changelog Unsure how to handle a situation Staff Documentation Investigating past staff action Moderation Log

If you are unsure, do not guess — escalate following the Staff Documentation.

docs.title: Change control (document-driven)
docs.text:
Any change to server behavior must:

  1. Follow the Staff Documentation’s authority structure
  2. Be recorded in the Server Changelog
  3. Be executed with a verified backup

docs.title: Incident or change?
docs.text:
Incident

  • Player-facing
  • Unplanned
  • Logged in the Moderation Log
  • Governed by Staff Documentation

Change

  • System-facing
  • Planned or corrective
  • Logged in the Server Changelog
  • Governed by Staff Documentation authority

docs.title: Escalation
docs.text:
All escalation paths are defined in the Staff Documentation.

When unsure:

  • Do not improvise
  • Do not bypass documentation
  • Escalate upward

docs.title: Module 4 completion check
docs.text:
You have completed this module if you can:

  • Identify which document governs a given situation
  • Explain the difference between authority, procedure, and record
  • Use the correct document without improvising
  • Escalate instead of acting when unsure

docs.title: Completion
docs.text:
Modules 1–4 establish the baseline operational knowledge required to safely participate in ERRSA MC server administration.

Advanced topics and specialization follow from here.

• Module 5 — Advanced Systems & Developer Responsibility Learn about stored data, external systems, and responsibilities that come with the developer role. Start Module 5

Last reviewed: 2025-02-13 | Applies to current ERRSA MC server network

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This module covers advanced systems that directly affect server integrity, data consistency, and long-term maintainability.

Access to these systems is granted by trust, not by completing modules.

This module exists to prevent irreversible damage.

docs.title: Advanced systems
docs.text:
Advanced systems are any components that:

  • Persist data outside the game world
  • Affect multiple servers at once
  • Cannot be safely “undone” in minutes
  • Can silently corrupt data if misused

docs.title: Databases & persistent data
docs.text:
The server uses external databases to store:

  • Player registration state
  • Email verification status
  • Cross-session identifiers

docs.title: Permissions architecture
docs.text: Permissions are a designed system, not a convenience tool.

docs.title: Network-level control
docs.text:
Velocity is the control plane for:

  • Entry points
  • Server isolation
  • Cross-server movement

docs.title: Plugin internals
docs.text: Plugins are not black boxes — but they are not playgrounds.

docs.title: Automation & scripts
docs.text: Automation increases impact — both good and bad.

docs.title: Environment separation
docs.text:
• Survival — live players, real data
  • Test — experimentation, validation

docs.title: Developer responsibility
docs.text: Developers are responsible not only for changes, but for the future consequences of those changes.

docs.title: Module 5 completion check
docs.text:
You have completed this module if you:

  • Treat access as responsibility, not privilege
  • Understand why restraint matters
  • Know when to escalate instead of acting
  • Can explain long-term risk, not just short-term fixes

docs.title: Completion
docs.text:
Modules 1–5 define the complete operational and technical training path for ERRSA MC server leadership.

From this point forward, learning is situational, documented, and responsibility-driven.

Last reviewed: 2025-02-13 | Applies to current ERRSA MC server network

docs.title: Issue: Bedrock players can’t click links (Discord/Feedback/Report).
docs.text:
Likely cause: Expected behavior-Bedrock is given plain text links by design.

Fix: Tell Bedrock players to copy/paste the link into a browser; keep links short and stable.

Escalate if: Java players also lose clickability-check chat formatting plugins that might strip click events.

Last verified: 2026-02-13 Server version: 1.21.4

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
Category: Core & Infrastructure

Floodgate enables Bedrock Edition players to join the ERRSA MC Java server through Geyser. It handles Bedrock player authentication, identity mapping, and Bedrock-specific permission handling.

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
Required for this plugin to function

  • Server: Paper 1.21.4
  • Plugins:
  • Geyser-Spigot

docs.title: Permissions Model
docs.text:
Permissions are intentionally scoped

Floodgate integrates with the parallel permission track model. Bedrock players are treated as normal players after initialization.

docs.title: Player permissions
docs.text:
• Bedrock players receive the same MAIN-track permissions as Java players
  • Permissions are applied after PlayerInitialization completes

Floodgate does not define gameplay permissions directly.

docs.title: Mod permissions
docs.text:
• None

Mods do not manage Floodgate behavior or Bedrock access.

docs.title: Admin permissions
docs.text:
• None

Admins do not configure Floodgate directly.

docs.title: Dev permissions
docs.text:
• Full configuration and maintenance
  • Bedrock authentication settings
  • UUID and prefix handling

docs.title: ERRSA Defaults & Settings
docs.text:
ERRSA-specific configuration choices

  • Online mode: Enabled — prevents spoofing
  • Username prefix: Enabled for Bedrock users — avoids name collisions
  • Auto-login: Disabled — authentication handled via PlayerInitialization
  • Command restrictions: Enforced until verification completes

These settings ensure Bedrock players follow the same lifecycle and verification flow as Java players.

Geyser allows Bedrock Edition clients to connect to the ERRSA MC Java server by translating Bedrock network traffic into Java-compatible packets.

Geyser does not modify gameplay rules, permissions, or authority; it only provides protocol compatibility.

Permissions Model
docs.text:
The ERRSA MC server uses three parallel permission tracks — not a single rank ladder. Each track answers a different question about a player.

  • MAIN: Can the player interact with gameplay?
  • ERRSA: Who is the player within ERRSA?
  • STAFF: What authority does the player have?

Key Rule

Permission tracks are parallel, not hierarchical. Membership in one track never implies power in another.

docs.title: Visual Overview
docs.text:
Interactive Permissions Model

Hover over each role to see what it means and what it does not imply.

MAIN Player Lifecycle
  • default unverified
  • user verified
  • premium VIP cosmetic
ERRSA Identity errsa hallrep legacy execcoord execboard advisor

Identity roles describe your relationship to ERRSA (not staff authority).

STAFF Authority
  • mod
  • admin
  • dev

docs.title: MAIN Track — Player Lifecycle
docs.text: Controls when a player can interact with gameplay.

docs.title: default — Unverified
docs.text:
• First join / unverified
  • Isolated (void)
  • Email verification only
  • ❌ No gameplay access

docs.title: user — Verified Player
docs.text:
• Full survival gameplay
  • Economy, claims, warps, voice chat

docs.title: premium — VIP Cosmetic Overlay
docs.text:
• Prefixes, QoL, cosmetics
  • ✅ Cosmetic-only benefits
  • ❌ Never grants authority

MAIN Track Boundary

MAIN determines play state, not staff power. VIP status does not grant moderation or admin abilities.

docs.title: ERRSA Track — Organization & Identity
docs.text: Controls who someone is within ERRSA.

docs.title: Groups
docs.text:
• errsa
  • hallrep
  • legacy
  • execcoord
  • execboard
  • advisor

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Prefixes and recognition
  • Organizational identity only

Hard Boundary

ERRSA identity groups never grant moderation, admin, or developer permissions.

docs.title: STAFF Track — Authority
docs.text: Controls actions that affect other players or the server.

docs.title: mod — Moderation
docs.text:
• Enforce rules
  • Mute / kick / ban
  • Investigate players
  • View logs, alerts, socialspy

Does NOT grant:

  • ❌ Rollbacks or fixes
  • ❌ Claim overrides
  • ❌ Operator (OP)

docs.title: admin — Operations
docs.text:
• Rollbacks and damage restoration
  • Claim and protection overrides
  • Incident resolution
  • Staff coordination

Does NOT grant:

  • ❌ Plugin installation
  • ❌ Config editing
  • ❌ LuckPerms modification
  • ❌ Operator (OP)

Admins support devs but do not replace them.

docs.title: dev — Technical Authority
docs.text:
• Full system access (*)
  • Plugins and configs
  • Permissions architecture
  • Backend and stability

Operator Access

Only devs receive operator commands.

Change Control

  • Coordinate impactful changes with Admins
  • Follow backup procedures
  • Document all technical changes

Escalation Flow

Situation Escalate To Player behavior issue mod Damage or incident admin Plugins / configs / permissions dev

If Unsure

  • Escalate upward
  • Document the issue
  • Never self-assign permissions
